ADMITTING DX: ABDOMINAL PAIN
WORKING DX: ABDOMINAL PAIN
HISTORY:  PANCREATITIS.  RIGHT UPPER QUADRANT PAIN.

EXAM:  ABDOMINAL ULTRASOUND - LIMITED.  MULTIPLE TRANSCUTANEOUS SONOGRAPHIC IMAGES OF THE RIGHT UPPER QUADRANT ARE OBTAINED.

COMPARISON:  NONE.


FINDING(S):

PANCREAS:  ALL HETEROGENEOUS BUT DIFFICULT TO FULLY VISUALIZED DUE TO BOWEL GAS AND LOTS OF HETEROGENEOUS SURROUNDING TISSUE.

LIVER:  INCREASED ECHOGENICITY SUGGEST HEPATIC STEATOSIS. MEASURES 15 CM IN LONG AXIS.

GALLBLADDER:  REMOVED.

COMMON BILE DUCT:  MEASURES 4 MM IN DIAMETER.

RIGHT KIDNEY:  RIGHT KIDNEY MEASURES 11.0 CM IN LONG AXIS.  NO HYDRONEPHROSIS OR RENAL CALCULI.

VASCULAR: NO VISUALIZED AORTIC OR IVC ABNORMALITY.

IMPRESSION(S):
1.  POOR VISUALIZATION OF THE PANCREAS DUE TO BOWEL GAS AND SUSPECTED LOCALIZED INFLAMMATION.
2.  HEPATIC STEATOSIS.

Report
CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast
 
INDICATION:Vomiting and diarrhea
 
COMPARISON: October 2016
 
TECHNIQUE: Helically acquired noncontrast axial multidetector CT images
were obtained from the lung bases through the pelvis. Dose reduction
techniques to achieve ALARA were employed. 
 
Findings:
 
The lung bases are clear.
 
The  spleen, adrenal glands, pancreas, and visualized portions of the
bowel are unremarkable. There is an irregular hypodense lesion in the
left hepatic lobe. There is a horseshoe kidney.
 
No significant osseous abnormalities are identified.
 
IMPRESSION: Irregular hypodensity in the left hepatic lobe likely
represents asymmetric fatty deposition. Consider further evaluation with
a nonemergent hepatic mass protocol CT. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Images reviewed, interpreted, and dictated by Dr. Bill Boshell.
Transcribed by Lee Garrett, R.T. (R).
